headline: CNN Live Event/Special
subHeadline: The Last Alzheimer's Patient. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: PAMELA BROWN, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes, I can't wait to watch it. Dr. Sanjay Gupta, thanks so much. "THE LAST ALZHEIMER'S PATIENT" airs next on CNN.And thank you so much for joining us tonight. I'm Pamela Brown. I hope you have a wonderful rest of the evening.

utterances.speaker: BRIANNA KEILAR, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: A new report shows Alzheimer's disease is a growing problem. The number of patients is expected to double by the year 2050.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, FORMER CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Alzheimer's affects 55 million people globally.MARIA SHRIVER, FOUNDER, THE WOMEN'S ALZHEIMER'S MOVEMENT: Two thirds of those living with Alzheimer's are women.

utterances.speaker: JACQUELINE HOWARD, CNN HEALTH CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Alzheimer's and other types of dementia will cost the United States about $345 billion this year.GUPTA (voice-over): Alzheimer's disease. For far too long there's been too little good news.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: The results from a study of an experimental treatment shows that it failed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Clinical trials showed it didn't significantly improve brain function and memory.DR. RICHARD ISAACSON, PREVENTIVE NEUROLOGIST IND. ORG: 99 point something percent of Alzheimer's drugs fail.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Why is it so hard to find an effective treatment for Alzheimer's?

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: But over the last five years, I've been investigating breakthroughs. And now, finally, a bit of hope.DR. MARIA CARRILLO, ALZHEIMER'S ASSOCIATION CHIEF SCIENCE OFFICER: This is an absolutely transformational moment.

utterances.speaker: ISAACSON
utterances.sentences: Nowadays, we have multiple FDA approved.DR. DEAN ORNISH, PREVENTIVE MEDICINE RESEARCH INSTITUTE: Our genes are pre-dispositioned. Our genes are not our fate.

utterances.speaker: ISAACSON
utterances.sentences: Four of every 10 cases of dementia may be preventable.

utterances.speaker: CARRILLO
utterances.sentences: We must be able to slow or stop this disease now.CICI ZERBE, ALZHEIMER'S PATIENT: I could use a strong cup of coffee.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: This is Cici Zerbe and her husband John back in 2019.C. ZERBE: Will you come see Grandma?

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Cici is best described as the matriarch of a huge, tight-knit family. Over her 80 years on earth, she has created a rich life filled with love and lasting memories.C. ZERBE: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: But in early 2018, her family began to notice something had changed.JOHN ZERBE, CICI'S HUSBAND: She would forget things, couldn't remember what we were supposed to be doing, and it slowly got worse until she would repeat herself about three times. FRANNY DEFATTE, CICI'S DAUGHTER: At first she didn't believe us that she had it, you know, no, that's no big deal. I just repeat myself once in a while. Who cares? C. ZERBE: John, being the kindest husband in the world, he said, Cici, yes, you do, you do repeat yourself a lot. But there's something more, too. He said let's just, you know, let's go see a doctor.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: A neurologist diagnosed Cici with mild cognitive impairment and dementia due to Alzheimer's, and scans soon confirmed the worst. Her brain showed signs of the disease. Now Cici was no stranger to Alzheimer's. She had had loved ones she watched wither away slowly from it.C. ZERBE: My grandmother, she would sit forever and just twiddle her dress, and stare into space and wouldn't talk too much. J. ZERBE: Her mother they finally put her in a home because her father couldn't take care of her. My greatest fears were that she would end up like her mother and grandmother, where I couldn't take care of her. DANIELLE ALLEN, CICI'S GRANDDAUGHTER: It was a hard word to hear, Alzheimer's. It hit really deep. You know, you don't want to lose your grandma. [20:05:01]

utterances.speaker: DEFATTE
utterances.sentences: The worst part was seeing my mom being uncomfortable going to parties and not feed herself. And the person that we love and not be confident in herself like she always has been.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: When the doctor told you and you got your cognitive testing, how did they tell you?C. ZERBE: Well, I had an office visit to get all the results of the tests and he said, well, there is a memory problem but I have the best place for you. And that was here in Sausalito. GUPTA (voice-over): And that's where I first met Cici and John five years ago. I've made my way to Sausalito, California. I'm going to spend time here with this world renown doctor who believes he's figured out a way not just to prevent Alzheimer's but to reverse it.

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: When people get diagnosed with Alzheimer's, it's a progressively isolating experience.GUPTA (voice-over): In 1990, Dr. Dean Ornish changed the medical world with his groundbreaking work on heart disease. His randomized clinical trial was the first to show that coronary heart disease could be reversed with nothing more than stress reduction, social support, diet, and exercise.

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: Part of the value of science is to increase awareness.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: While Ornish's approach has sometimes been criticized for being too strict, not practical enough, some others have pointed out a lack of research showing that plant-based diets could definitively decrease disease. But Ornish turns to his decades of work as proof.

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: You really can eat more and weigh less if you know what to eat.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: That what is good for the heart is almost certainly good for the brain.

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: The same lifestyle changes could reverse high blood pressure, high cholesterol, type two diabetes, obesity, early stage prostate cancer can be slowed, stopped, even reversed. And now we're hoping to show that these same lifestyle changes may reverse the progression of early stage Alzheimer's.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Five years ago in the early stages of the study.Do you remember what you're experiencing before your diagnosis?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I couldn't formulate words.GUPTA (voice-over): I spent some time with patients and their support partners for their four-hour long, three-day-a-week meetings. And I got a really detailed look at the Ornish Lifestyle Intervention Program. The exercise, the yoga, and the meditation regimen. Sitting in on their support groups and eating the provided plant-based meals. What do you tell the participants in the trial?

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: Well, we tell them that we don't know if this is going to work, but we hope that it does. If you're trying to give people the message that you can reverse something then you need to have really solid science from randomized trials before doing that.GUPTA (voice-over): It all matters preserving, even restoring the memories of a life well-lived. C. ZERBE: That no matter what happens if I don't get better just know that somewhere deep down outside my brain, I will always love him.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Now, again, that meeting in Sausalito was five years ago. Seemingly a lifetime has passed since then. A global pandemic shut down the world. Driving up loneliness and disconnection. But in 2024, we finally got word. Dr. Ornish was ready to release his findings to us.Five years ago one of the things that you are trying to figure out is, could those lifestyle changes in some people actually lead to a reversal of Alzheimer's disease?

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: What's the answer?

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: The answer is in many people it did.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I mean, it's extraordinary, reversing something that seems so preordained. It's fixed. This is my life now, it sounds extraordinary.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: How's that feeling?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Good.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Good? OK.GUPTA (voice-over): It is the first randomized controlled clinical trials showing that some Alzheimer's patients could experience cognitive improvement in just five months, with intensive lifestyle changes alone.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Rising up into the middle back.

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: So the more you change, the more you improve. But to get reversal, you have to make really big changes. GUPTA

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes, and it's not just a vegan diet, you know, Twinkies are vegan, you know. It's a healthy vegan diet. It's fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, soy products, as close to possible as they come in nature.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: A half an hour to an hour of moderate or brisk activity, four, three times a week, and group support, and there was yoga-slash- meditation. You could do it in a secular way, you could do it however you want to do it.

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes. For an hour a day.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: For an hour a day.

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: It's a big commitment.GUPTA (voice-over): A big commitment but also doable. Cici did it. And now I wanted to see how she was doing. It has been five years since she first joined that study. Hey, Cici. C. ZERBE: Sanjay.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: How are you?C. ZERBE: I'm good, I'm a lot better now. Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: It's good to see you.C. ZERBE: Same here.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: It's been five years.C. ZERBE: I can't believe it.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: How have you been?C. ZERBE: I have been great. I've been fine. I live with this man who has the patience of a saint and that helps. That helps. J. ZERBE: Cici is doing very well. She goes out in the morning. She'll go for a walk. Almost every morning she goes for a walk. I think she's doing very well.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Does it surprise you?J. ZERBE: Yes, after seeing her mother and grandmother, yes. Because I was triggered by this tension of being in a home or something.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: How are you doing now do you think as compared to five years ago?C. ZERBE: Much better. Much better. GUPTA: Did this help reverse some of the symptoms of Alzheimer's? C. ZERBE: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I guess the question is, why, right? What do you attribute this to?C. ZERBE: The program, the meditation, the diet, the exercise. My choice of a meal before this was a breaded veal cutlet. I haven't had one in five years. GUPTA (voice-over): And there is this other crucial element. You got to have a partner. J. ZERBE: Want a piece of bread? Here. C. ZERBE: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: John did every step of the program right alongside Cici.J. ZERBE: The food was a little bit hard to get used to. I miss my biscuits and gravy. We're just doing without for now.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Cici is now 85 years old. John, 92.

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: For Cici, she was initially randomly assigned to the comparison group of our study. So she didn't make changes for the first 20 weeks and she got worse, and then she crossover got the program since then she's shown improvement in three of the four tests and no change in one of them.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: So for the first 20 weeks, she was sort of living her life?

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: And everything worsened.

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: It also shows you how dynamic these biological mechanisms are in both directions. You can get better quickly, you can get worse quickly.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: OK. Everybody good? I got to say this is a good looking family here.(Voice-over): I had a chance to sit down with a few members of the Zerbe family. Cici and John, you guys have done well. (Voice-over): Including their daughters Franny and Alicia. Alicia, I don't want to overstate the impact of this or understate it. I want to be just really fair about this. For people who may be dealing with this, how would you describe the impact that this program has had on Cici? ALICIA MANZONI, CICI'S DAUGHTER: Tremendous. It's really helped. It's I think slowed it down. It's just amazing in my opinion.

utterances.speaker: DEFATTE
utterances.sentences: I mean, how many people five years into dementia get to go outside and go for a walk by themselves every day? Not very many.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Cici, I remember when we spoke back in 2019, you were very clear with me that one of your greatest fears was going through the same thing you had seen with your mom and your grandma. Do you still fear that?C. ZERBE: No, I think I passed that a long time ago.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: That's kind of incredible.C. ZERBE: Yes. And here I am.

utterances.speaker: ISAACSON
utterances.sentences: We'll look at your body composition.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: So that's why I decided to do something quite personal.

utterances.speaker: ISAACSON
utterances.sentences: Your muscle mass, your body fat.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Quite revealing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: That wasn't quite right.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I went through a battery of tests to assess my own risk.

utterances.speaker: ISAACSON
utterances.sentences: Just like we get a cholesterol test every year and check your blood pressure, got to do the same thing for the brain.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: And what did I find?

utterances.speaker: ISAACSON
utterances.sentences: I'll just say it.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: That's coming up. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: So we've made our way to Miami now. By the year 2050 it is expected that more than 152 million people around the world will be diagnosed with Alzheimer's. It's part of the urgency of these researchers and why they're working so hard and so fast to try and get things done.(Voice-over): That vital work is happening at places like the University of Miami Miller School of Medicine. So every brain that we're seeing here, the inhibiter of these brains at one point had Alzheimer's disease. Is that right? DR. DAVID DAVIS, ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR, BRAIN ENDOWMENT BANK: That's correct. The majority of these brains, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: You know, the most amazing thing is when I was in medical school in the early 1990s, the conventional wisdom was, you got a certain number of brain cells and that was it. Over your life you could drain the cash. Things like alcohol might speed up that process but you got what you got. By the time I finished in the year 2000 everything had changed. We realized that you could continue to grow new brain cells which was kind of incredible.

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.sentences: Our goal is to make sure that we get high-quality donations that could be used by investigators all around the world.GUPTA (voice-over): Dr. David Davis is the associate director of the Brain Endowment Bank.

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.sentences: All in the cause of better understanding the progression of the disease and potentially hopefully finding therapies and cures.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: I started training in neurosurgery 30 years ago. And still every time I look at the human brain, I am still filled with awe. Everything we are is located right here. Every love, every memory, every desire. All here in this enigmatic 3.5 pounds of tissue.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How are your memory?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Not so good.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Are you able to remember my name, for example?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: We've come a long way since then. We can now peer into the brain when the patient is very much alive.DR. RONALD PETERSEN, MAYO CLINIC ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE RESEARCH CENTER: These are PET scans that pick up the two proteins in the brain that define Alzheimer's disease, amyloid and tau. The redness indicates that the amyloid protein is present. So that's the protein that makes up the plaque. One of the defining features.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Dr. Ronald Petersen is director of the Mayo Clinic Alzheimer's Disease Research Center.

utterances.speaker: PETERSEN
utterances.sentences: The amyloid protein that gets laid down in the brain. This can happen up to 10, 15, 20 years before a person become symptomatic. So many people are out there walking around with some amyloid in the brain, but they're doing fine clinically.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Connie Grumdahl is one of those people. Lots of amyloid in the brain but zero symptoms.CONNIE GRUMDAHL, ALZHEIMER'S STUDY PARTICIPANT: So I know that I do have plaque in my brain. I don't understand how that affects some people and not others. Nice to meet you as well so much.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: We first met Connie at Dr. Petersen's clinic five years ago in 2019. And at the time, 69-year-old Connie was halfway through a highly anticipated Alzheimer's study called the A4 trial. It was designed for those with plaque in their brains but so far living a normal life.

utterances.speaker: GRUMDAHL
utterances.sentences: So I'm one of 19 children.

utterances.speaker: PETERSEN
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GRUMDAHL
utterances.sentences: Number 18.

utterances.speaker: PETERSEN
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GRUMDAHL
utterances.sentences: And three of my sisters have died. I have two in memory care. So it's personal.Hello, how are you? You look so beautiful today. You have a lot of pictures from --

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Today we listen in on an extraordinary visit to the memory care ward. Connie has come to see her sister, Vera, who is 12 years older.

utterances.speaker: GRUMDAHL
utterances.sentences: We're in order of how we were born.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Again in a family of 19 children. GRUMDAHLVERA LOIS ERICKSON, CONNIE'S SISTER: And so is this one right here.

utterances.speaker: GRUMDAHL
utterances.sentences: OK. Here we go. This is what you wrote a long time ago for your doctorate when you were --

utterances.speaker: ERICKSON
utterances.sentences: I put it in here.

utterances.speaker: GRUMDAHL
utterances.sentences: Yes. This is all your work.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Vera was once a trailblazing psychology professor at the University of Minnesota. A loving mother, grandmother. About seven years ago, though, her memory started to fade and the decline was steep.

utterances.speaker: GRUMDAHL
utterances.sentences: One night she'd left the house in the middle of the night and we didn't find her until noon the next day. Today with Vera, it was one of the most special days that I've had in a long time with her. Looking at my family history, my brothers are fine, my sisters are not. But some of my sisters are. Will I be a lucky one? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Those confusing unanswered questions are what fuel Connie and what fuels the scientists who are caring for her. In 2019, she was midway through the four-and-a-half year study to try and prevent what she had seen happened to her older sister. Even during the pandemic, Connie would drive more than an hour each way from her home in Minneapolis to the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota. She would undergo cognitive, motor, and general health testing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: And we are going to be giving you research IRB. That's the Lenon's map (PH).

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: And almost every month.

utterances.speaker: GRUMDAHL
utterances.sentences: Oh, I can feel that going.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: She would receive this IV transfusion.

utterances.speaker: GRUMDAHL
utterances.sentences: So this is, what, about an hour? It's time consuming. I feel like I'm contributing even if it's not for me. It's for research, and it might help my kids, it might help my grandkids or the greater good.

utterances.speaker: PETERSEN
utterances.sentences: When you're dealing with people who get enrolled in a clinical trial, it's important to really be realistic to say, we're hopeful that the drug that you may receive is going to help us with treating this underlying disease. But there's a possibility it could go in the other direction.

utterances.speaker: GRUMDAHL
utterances.sentences: You either agree to that risk or you don't. I don't have an alternative right now.I love you. I'll walk you in.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: The long-awaited results were finally in.

utterances.speaker: SPERLING
utterances.sentences: We did not unfortunately slow the cognitive decline with this particular antibody.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Disappointing findings for patients like Connie, who is now 74 years old.

utterances.speaker: CARRILLO
utterances.sentences: The A4 Study, it turned out that the approach is right. The drug was not the right one.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Lessons learned. That laid the foundation for newer drugs like one you may have heard of. Lecanemab.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: A potential breakthrough this morning for millions of Americans affected by Alzheimer's. A new antibody treatment for the disease could slow the progression of cognitive decline by 27 percent.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: There's not been a significant treatment that has had this degree of improvement in these patients really in a long time, if ever.(Voice-over): Lecanemab or Leqembi is part of a new class of drugs called monoclonal antibodies. They are given every other week. A similar drug, Donanemab, is administered monthly. Let me show you how they work. Remember beta amyloid? That's the sticky compound of protein fragments that can accumulate in the brain and can clump together to form amyloid plaques, disrupting cellular communication and eventually cause neuronal death. Well, these new drugs stimulate the immune system to attack some of the building blocks of these amyloid proteins and eventually break up the plaques. But it is important to note that there are potential side effects.

utterances.speaker: HOWARD
utterances.sentences: Some of those adverse events or side effects in a small percentage of the Lecanemab group, including brain swelling and brain bleeding.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: It's not a homerun, but there's been so little progress when it comes to Alzheimer's. This incremental progress is important.

utterances.speaker: PETERSEN
utterances.sentences: Lecanemab slowed the rate of progression by about 27 percent.GUPTA (voice-over): 27 percent. It's enough for someone like 73-year- old Barbara Otis (PH).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So are you ready for this, dear?BARBARA OTIS, ALZHEIMER'S PATIENT: I am ready.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Alongside her husband Jim, she is here for her second Alzheimer's treatment with Lecanemab.

utterances.speaker: OTIS
utterances.sentences: I never thought this would happen to me. Let's go.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: She'll be coming here every other week for the next 18 months. Both retired teachers, she and Jim read to one another to pass the time.

utterances.speaker: OTIS
utterances.sentences: Kate sat by the firepit. The flames lighting up her face.Well, I hope to see that my memory is steadfast and everything is in place.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: So far there are approximately 2,000 people using the drug in the United States. And it's not cheap. This price for the medication is $26,500 per year. But Medicare does often cover a good portion of it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is the number one priority. So, you know, we have to sell the place or the house or whatever we have to do. This is a priority. We don't expect that that's going to happen, but we do what we're going to do.

utterances.speaker: OTIS
utterances.sentences: Be not afraid.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: They're teachers so no surprise they've studied all the data, all the papers, and they know the odds. But here's the thing. They're looking for more time to spend together and the chance for more scientific breakthroughs. Maybe even a cure.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: If in fact you can continue pushing this back, right, that maybe who knows that maybe that will be opened and you and others can be better.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Coming up, can Alzheimer's be prevented?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I would say, yes, drop all fried food.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: This is 71-year-old Mike Carver. Today he's at his Rock Steady boxing class in Berkeley, California. While Mike has no known family history of Alzheimer's, he was a carrier of both copies of the APOE4 gene. That's the genotype that can increase a person's risk at least tenfold and in 2017 he was diagnosed with early onset Alzheimer's.MIKE CARVER, EARLY ONSET ALZHEIMER'S PATIENT: All right. Time.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Mike, they tell you that this is the diagnosis and then do they tell you at all what to do about it?

utterances.speaker: CARVER
utterances.sentences: Not really. Just kind of go home and, you know, start putting things away.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Really?M. CARVER: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: That must have been really hard.PAT CARVER, WIFE OF EARLY ONSET ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE PATIENT: If there's something you want to do, do it in the next couple of years because we don't know how fast this will move.

utterances.speaker: ORNISH
utterances.sentences: Welcome, everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: Eventually, they found Dr. Dean Ornish and this clinical trial. That's the same one Cici Zerbe has been a part of.P. CARVER: It was probably only maybe three or four months into the study that I realized Mike wasn't asking repetitive questions the way he had been and those stopped and those have kind of stayed away.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: You're a meat and potatoes kind of guy.M. CARVER: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: They're asking you to do a vegan diet.M. CARVER: Yes. I'm from Kansas City. There's meat there. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: How hard was that for you?M. CARVER: It was pretty difficult to start with, then I just had to turn around and say, this is the best I can do to stay alive, and I want to live with my wife as long as I can. GUPTA (voice-over): Dr. Ornish reports that after 40 weeks, Mike's cognitive tests improved. P. CARVER: Our neurologist said, honestly, he has never had a patient actually show an improvement on a score. He was pretty amazed about that. And actually it was kind of shocking. M. CARVER: Yes. P. CARVER: That was kind of when he was like at his best.

utterances.speaker: GUPTA
utterances.sentences: They were in the Ornish study during COVID and they had to move the four-hour, three-time-a-week group sessions to Zoom. They enjoy their support group so much that they still meet weekly all these years later. Throughout the study, they both lost weight.
